guide.conclusion:
When the stain is dry, it is quite clean. PVC stained using this technique will pass a "white glove test" and will not transfer color, under normal conditions, to materials that come in contact with it.

If you're feeling really adventurous, you might also try setting a coil in the cable before staining it.

At some point I hope to experiment with spray application of these stains.
guide.introduction:
If you want an extension cord, power cord, or other plastic-insulated cable in an unusual color, and you can find one in white, there's a good chance you can dye it to suit your preference using this technique.

Turns out many cables are sheathed with PVC, and will take the same oil-based stains as PVC pipe. If you want a purple cord, for instance, you can just treat a white PVC cord with purple primer. If you want some other color, it is easy to prepare your own custom stains from clear PVC cleaner and concentrated solvent dyes.
guide.introduction_rendered:
If you want an extension cord, power cord, or other plastic-insulated cable in an unusual color, and you can find one in white, there's a good chance you can dye it to suit your preference using this technique.

Turns out many cables are sheathed with PVC, and will take the same oil-based stains as PVC pipe. If you want a purple cord, for instance, you can just treat a white PVC cord with purple primer. If you want some other color, it is easy to prepare your own custom stains from clear PVC cleaner and concentrated solvent dyes.

Relevant parts
  • Cord or cable
Tools
  • Gloves
  • Lighter fluid
  • Multimeter or Continuity Tester
  • PVC Stain
  • Paper towels
  • Plastic sheet
  • Towel
  • Tray

lines.text: Not all plastic insulation will take this dye.  Test a small piece of the insulation you want to stain before trying to do a whole cable.
lines.text_raw: Not all plastic insulation will take this dye.  Test a small piece of the insulation you want to stain before trying to do a whole cable.

lines.text: You can perform this test using hardware-store purple primer.  If the material will take a purple primer stain, this technique will work.
lines.text_raw: You can perform this test using hardware-store purple primer.  If the material will take a purple primer stain, this technique will work.

lines.text: Observe all safety warnings on the can of PVC cleaner or primer that holds your stain.  Work in a well-ventilated area, away from open flame, and protect your skin with nitrile gloves.
lines.text_raw: Observe all safety warnings on the can of PVC cleaner or primer that holds your stain.  Work in a well-ventilated area, away from open flame, and protect your skin with nitrile gloves.

lines.text: Lay a plastic garbage bag, painter's dropcloth, or other plastic sheeting over your bench top.
lines.text_raw: Lay a plastic garbage bag, painter's dropcloth, or other plastic sheeting over your bench top.

lines.text: Set a metal tray on top of the plastic sheet.  I use an old aluminum cookie sheet measuring 12x18".
lines.text_raw: Set a metal tray on top of the plastic sheet.  I use an old aluminum cookie sheet measuring 12x18".

lines.text: Put two or three layers of paper towel on top of the metal tray.
lines.text_raw: Put two or three layers of paper towel on top of the metal tray.

lines.text: To one side, set a folded shopcloth, rag, or towel that you don't mind getting grubby.  This will couch the cord while it's drying.
lines.text_raw: To one side, set a folded shopcloth, rag, or towel that you don't mind getting grubby.  This will couch the cord while it's drying.

lines.text: Apply the stain to the cord, directly from the can, using the applicator built into the cap.  Try to avoid letting it drip or pool on the cable itself.
lines.text_raw: Apply the stain to the cord, directly from the can, using the applicator built into the cap.  Try to avoid letting it drip or pool on the cable itself.

lines.text: The stain dries very quickly. As each section of the cord dries, feed it to the side, onto the towel, and move on to the next section,
lines.text_raw: The stain dries ''very'' quickly.  As each section of the cord dries, feed it to the side, onto the towel, and move on to the next section,

lines.text: Don't worry about getting stain on the metal prongs of the plug.  The metal will not take the stain, and any that dries there is easy to clean off.  See below.
lines.text_raw: Don't worry about getting stain on the metal prongs of the plug.  The metal will not take the stain, and any that dries there is easy to clean off.  See below.

lines.text: Leave the cable undisturbed on the towel for at least half an hour, which should be more than enough time for the stain to thoroughly dry.
lines.text_raw: Leave the cable undisturbed on the towel for at least half an hour, which should be more than enough time for the stain to thoroughly dry.

lines.text: The plastic child-safety clip on my extension cord was made of some different kind of plastic, that did not take the stain, so I just clipped it off with a pair of side-cutters.
lines.text_raw: The plastic child-safety clip on my extension cord was made of some different kind of plastic, that did not take the stain, so I just clipped it off with a pair of side-cutters.

lines.text: For touch-up work, the applicator should be just slightly dampened with stain.
lines.text_raw: For touch-up work, the applicator should be just slightly dampened with stain.

lines.text: Dip the applicator in the stain and daub it first against the inside of the can, and then at least once on a paper towel.
lines.text_raw: Dip the applicator in the stain and daub it first against the inside of the can, and then at least once on a paper towel.

lines.text: Smooth over any light spots or splotches using the damp applicator.  It may take a few strokes before the plastic softens and the color begins to even out.
lines.text_raw: Smooth over any light spots or splotches using the damp applicator.  It may take a few strokes before the plastic softens and the color begins to even out.

lines.text: Plug prongs or other metal parts will not take the stain, and stray dye can be wiped off using a paper towel moistened with lighter fluid.
lines.text_raw: Plug prongs or other metal parts will not take the stain, and stray dye can be wiped off using a paper towel moistened with lighter fluid.

lines.text: Alternately, you can just wash metal parts in a stream of lighter fluid from the bottle.  A small amount of dye may wash from adjacent plastic, but it should not be enough to noticeably affect the color.
lines.text_raw: Alternately, you can just wash metal parts in a stream of lighter fluid from the bottle.  A small amount of dye may wash from adjacent plastic, but it should not be enough to noticeably affect the color.

lines.text: Although it is unlikely that this technique will significantly affect the integrity of the insulation, you should err on the side of caution and carefully test the cable before using it.
lines.text_raw: Although it is unlikely that this technique will significantly affect the integrity of the insulation, you should err on the side of caution and carefully test the cable before using it.

lines.text: Set your multimeter to check continuity--most of them beep to indicate a closed circuit.
lines.text_raw: Set your multimeter to check continuity--most of them beep to indicate a closed circuit.

lines.text: Connect one probe to one contact at one end of the cable.
lines.text_raw: Connect one probe to one contact at one end of the cable.

lines.text: Touch the other probe to the contacts at the other end of the cable and verify that there are no shorts.
lines.text_raw: Touch the other probe to the contacts at the other end of the cable and verify that there are no shorts.

guide.summary: Stain cords and cables any color you like.
guide.title: Cable Dyeing

tools.notes: Purple primer is available from the hardware store, or you can make your own custom stain using our earlier guide on the subject.
